Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: New Technologies for Querying Pathway Databases

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Unlike most bioinformatics data, such as DNA sequences and protein
structures, pathways show the interactions of different bio-chemical
entities. Thus, each entity or subpathway can have a function in its
pathway that the pathway can not realize without it. Formulating these
functions presents exciting computational challenges.

This proposal develops algorithms for efficient and accurate
computational analysis of pathways. The first step in achieving this
goal is to build a mathematical model for functions of pathways and
subpathways. This proposal defines the function of a subpathway as its
contribution to the steady state of the entire pathway. Computing this
contribution is a difficult problem especially for gene regulatory
pathways. Existing methods can compute this for metabolic pathways,
but they do not scale to even medium sized gene regulatory
pathways. This proposal develops efficient methods for computing
function.

Finding the subpathway that has a desired function is a challenging
problem. There is no clear way of searching for subpathways with
desired functions using existing tools. This proposal develops
efficient algorithms for searching subpathways with desired function.
This proposal takes this one step further, and develops mathematically
sound algorithms for comparing two pathways so that the entities that
map are functionally, homologically and topologically similar. This
proposal also explores feature and reference-based index structures
for biological pathway databases.

Further information on the project can be found at the project web
page:
http://bioinformatics.cise.ufl.edu/

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual merit

This project developed novel algorithms for efficient and accurate computational analysis of biological networks. Each entity or a subnetwork serves a set of functions that are defined not solely based on the contents of that entity or subnetwork, but rather the entire network it interacts with. Formulating these functions is a biologically important and computationally challenging task. This project conjectures that the function of a subnetwork is defined as its contribution to the steady state of the entire pathway. Computing this contribution is a difficult problem especially for gene regulatory pathways.  Existing methods can compute this for metabolic pathways, but they do not scale to even medium sized gene regulatory pathways. To address these challenges, this project has tackled the following major problems


  • We developed novel algorithms for identifying subnetworks with desired functions.

  • We developed novel methods for aligning two pathways considering their functional and structural similarities.

  • We developed efficient feature-based and reference-based index structures for querying biological network databases.


We have published the results of this project in numerous articles in premier journals and proceedings.


Broader Impacts


This project has achieved and surpassed the goals we set for broader impacts. Following summarizes them.


  • The articles we published have been cited in different venues and the tools we have developed have been used in biological network analysis.

  • The methods we have developed extended beyond biological networks at the molecular level to ecological networks, food-webs, phylogenetic trees, and social networks.

  • The project supported training of nine PhD and one MS students towards their degrees. This project also helped in training of two post doctoral, three undergraduate students by having them participate in solving the  problems considered within its  scope.

  • The PI has developed a new graduate/undergraduate level research course. The PI has integrated the problems considered in this project in that course and in the graduate level boninformatics course.

 


Last Modified: 06/15/2015
Modified by: Tamer Kahveci
